content.text: How would you name this kitten?

You are being recorded.
press [SPACE] to continue

items.title: Thank you for participating in this important research!

items.content:
Press any key to continue and download the data as a CSV file. The audio recordings are encoded as Base64 strings in the 'audio' column. Base64 can be converted to an audio file using a Python/R/JavaScript script or a website such as Base64 guru..

Note: The string cannot be directly decoded as Base64 without first removing the Data-URL declaration preceding the Base64-encoded data. To retrieve only the Base64 encoded string, first remove "data:*/*;base64," from the result! That is, 

data:audio/ogg; codecs=opus;base64,
is not part of the Base64 and has to be removed before storing it as audio!

Once extracted, the filetype of the audio is `.ogg`. Not all media players can play ogg files (for example, Windows Groove can't). VLC is a good free audio player that can.
items.title: Download data
Running on JATOS
items.content: You can run this study in JATOS, too. In that case it will not offer to download the data at the end, but instead store it on JATOS. You can find more information in the lab.js docs.

content.text:
Browsers will block audio recording and playback 
if the user has not interacted with the page yet. 
Adding a welcome screen like this one will solve that issue.
Press the [SPACE] key to begin the experiment.

Not all keys work in all browsers, for example, the arrow key don't
seem to work in Chrome. It's better to instruct the user to use a 
specific key rather than 'any key'.

items.title: Audio recorder test
items.content:
Use the record button below to test if the recording works, 
then press the <kbd>Space</kbd> key to continue.

metadata.title: lab.js audio recording example
metadata.description:
This is an example script for recording audio during a trial. 

- There is a "test audio" screen that demonstrates the use of a button to start and stop the recording
- Two "trial" screens demonstrate automatic recording (recording starts when the screen loads and ends when the screen ends)

This is based on a script by Kwame Porter Robinson (https://github.com/robinsonkwame/lab-js-recording-task)
